Award.AwardTitle: LTP and the Spaced Trials Effect
Award.AbstractNarration: A long "cramming" session is a much less effective way of learning than are multiple training sessions separated by an hour or more (i.e., spaced trials). Does this basic characteristic of learning reflect limits imposed by an unrecognized feature of the brain mechanisms that encode memory? If so, is it possible to circumvent these limits so as to accelerate learning? The present work builds on recent discoveries from this investigator's laboratory to address these fundamental questions. Techniques targeted at different neurobehavioral levels will be used: i) electrical recordings from brain cells to analyze memory-related changes, ii) locally developed light microscopy techniques to measure chemical signaling at the junction between two brain cells (i.e., synapses), and iii) behavioral procedures for measuring learning by animals in naturalistic, complex environments. Previous work by this investigator showed that an unusual class of brain proteins called integrins regulates synapses in a memory-related brain region and that these proteins have novel properties that produce a phenomenon at the level of the synapse that resembles the spaced trials effect seen in learning studies. Because the time frame under study approximates that of a classroom session, these studies could add an entirely new dimension to brain-based strategies for improving education. They will also suggest pharmacological means for manipulating the timing rules that govern the formation of stable memories. Finally, the program will provide a unique opportunity for students (undergraduate through post-doctoral), several of whom are from minority groups, to work together on a problem that is critical to basic science and as well to society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Psychologists have known since the 19th century that memory is most efficiently encoded when an individual uses temporally separated learning sessions rather than a single cramming period. Why is this so? Our research using rodents indicates that unexpected properties of synapses, the storage sites for memory, contribute importantly to this fundamental feature of learning. The studies were conducted using the hippocampus, a relatively small structure that plays a vital role in the formation of new memories. Relatedly, hippocampal synapses have a remarkable capacity for rapid modification: when activated by a pattern of input corresponding to that found during learning, they quickly increase their potency for weeks or longer. Extensive research from many laboratories showed that this long-term potentiation (LTP) effect is the long sought substrate for commonplace forms of memory. Our NSF project began with the discovery that a second application of patterned activation causes already modified connections to undergo a further, large increase in their strength but only if it was delayed by one hour. This result describes a correspondence between a ubiquitous aspect of learning and a surprising characteristic of synapses. Behavioral studies then showed that the one-hour rule for LTP results in a several fold increase in memory and offsets the learning impairments in a mouse model of autism.   

            Science involves searching for ever-deeper explanations. In the case of the LTP spaced trials effect, the question became one of what types of synaptic mechanisms could account for the required one-hour delay. We addressed this by turning to the cell biology of the potentiation phenomenon. Studies using an imaging technology developed in our laboratory revealed that adhesion receptors in synapses have a property not reported for other types of cell junctions: once activated they enter a quiescent period lasting for one hour. This peculiar effect proved to be linked to the synaptic spaced trials effect but in an unexpected way. Experiments showed that many contacts formed by the stimulated input don’t enter the LTP state after the first bout of patterned activation but do so after a second bout delivered in the presence of re-engaged adhesion receptors. In essence, spacing expands the memory trace rather than strengthening already encoded data.  

            The optimal interval for spaced learning depends on the type of material being acquired. This raises the possibility that different populations of synaptic connections have different plasticity mechanisms and so timing rules other than those summarized above. We tested this by comparing LTP in various hippocampal pathways and found that one of these, which carries semantic (‘what is it’) information, uses singular encoding mechanisms. As predicted, these synapses have very different spacing rules for LTP. We then found that even the basic processing of signals is not the same across the networks. These results needs to be considered in light of the now large body of research showing that the hippocampus assembles diverse material into codes for episodic memory. This is a record of a series of events, placed into an autobiographical narrative containing the items that you saw (‘what’), their locations (‘where’), and the sequence in which they occurred (‘when’). Our studies indicate that different machinery encodes the components of an episode, a conclusion that calls for substantial revision to current hypotheses about the role of hippocampus in assembling this core element of human cognition. We are using biologically realistic computer simulations to develop a model that incorporates this large body of experimental data on plasticity and signal transformations and have recently described a first set of intriguing results. The next step is to ask if simulations can actually encode an episodic memory.  

Beyond the intellectual merit of identifying neurobiological mechanism of learning, and specifically of spaced training, support for this project had the broader impact of addressing goals of education, training and public information. The laboratory work engaged undergraduate students who were trained in tthe scientific method (experimental design, execution, and analysis) and exposed to career opportunities in the field of Neuroscience.  In addition, PhD students engaged in the work made progress toward their degrees but also actively participated in outreach to high school students and the lay community in acting as 'experts' in blogs pertaining to science and the brain in particular. Finally,PI Gary Lynch gave lectures to the UCI minority student program and the lay community, and participated in an NSF organized meeting on Capital Hill to provide an update on advances in Neuroscience to congressional representatives.
